Text: Yeah. So you obviously do some training around water systems. Do you ever get to talk

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: to lay people in the region or in the community about water stuff?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Do you mean not water plant operators? Just citizens?

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Yeah. The community. The public.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah. Probably more when I was [REDACTED]. But yeah I guess just because even we'll be

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: at the clinic in a village and the health aid will comment about the water. So yeah. I guess

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: we've talked to people occasionally who aren't water plant operators about the water.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: So, do you have an example?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Of negative feedback?

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: I mean about piped water or about fluoride or about why people need to be nice to their

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: water plant operator or about?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Well, I can tell you I ran out of water yesterday. I complained but I don't know. It's tough.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: We always do this during the holidays because they deliver a week ahead. Sorry they

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: deliver a day ahead. And so at the end of it, you end up with an extra day in yourâ€¦

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Whatever. An extra day of your having to squeeze an extra day out of your water and we

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: ran out last night. But my gosh. Something someone's complained about with water.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [REDACTED]. The [REDACTED] water systems because the city of [REDACTED] water

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: systems. [REDACTED].

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: That they have relatively poor water quality. But it meets drinking water standards. They

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: do all their testing they're supposed to but it comes out of the pipes occasionally not clear.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I'm still not sure about it because [REDACTED] lives in [REDACTED]. And whenever people

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: complain about it he's like, "I don'tâ€¦" He's like, "We don't see that." So I don't know if it's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: just certain areas of [REDACTED] orâ€¦ I don't know. That's been one of the biggest

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: mysteries to me and it's super concerning, [REDACTED]. As a [REDACTED], you're like, "My

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: God, we need to do something about this." But I don't know.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Well and a lot of times it's people's own house too, right? If the pipes from the connection

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: to your sink are gross. But yeah at myâ€¦ I live on the other water system and I run in-line

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: filters and it filters out a bunch of nasty stuff from my water too.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Mm-hmm (affirmative). I haven't heard much about fluoride recently though. I don't ever.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I think people here don't even think about it for the most part.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: It got batted down. The last time people had concerns about it, their concerns were

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: batted down pretty quickly. It just didn't seem like [REDACTED] was a place to have a fight

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: about fluoride.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah. I remember in [REDACTED] though, [REDACTED] ago, when we all watched the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: streaming. That was a circus.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: So, I'm just going over some notes here. Are there things that are different talking to the

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: public versus talking to water plant operators? I'm thinking of end users and you

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: mentioned the thing with water quality and I think you're hitting on some of the

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: challenges of it's really hard to nail down even what's wrong sometimes.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Mm-hmm (affirmative). Yeah, definitely. Between talking with water plant operators and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: lay people, yeah. There's a big difference in knowledge and expectations and, I don't

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: know. I think a lot of people don't realize what goes into the water at a water treatment

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: plant. That's when maybe sometimes they find out and think, "Chemicals shouldn't be in

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: my water." And all that. But I would say that people know. In the villages I think people

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: are more aware maybe or think about it more. That there's chlorine in the water and that

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: there's chemicals. And I think that's why a lot of times they still prefer their traditional

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: sources. I know that's definitely true in probably almost everywhere people have a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: traditional source. But I knowâ€¦ I think it's [REDACTED]. There's a stream that everybody

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: loves to go haul water from. Or a mountain stream or something. I know they're up on

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: hills over there. But, yeah. I think most people not knowing anything about the chemicals

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: would rather have a raw water or a surface water or some out of a mountain or

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: something.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: We ran into that actually a lot with the water plant operators. [REDACTED] we start out

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and we're like, "Look, I know you might have other sources. But for the purpose of this

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: class and for taking the test and everything, treated water is safe. Untreated water,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: surface water is unknown and therefore probably not safe." And so we have to really

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: make that clear because a lot of the community, anecdotally, I can say that people don't

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: drink the water. They have a drinking water source, a drinking water system. Like

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [REDACTED], they don't have good water quality. It's not listed as a GWUDI or whatever,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: groundwater under surface water influence. It's not listed as that type of system but

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: everyone knows it is. And so they have salt water intrusion in their groundwater well. And

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: people say no one drinks the water without running it through some other filter or a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Berkey or a RO or distiller.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I think that's the thing theyâ€¦ A lot of times. At the clinic for a long time they had a distiller.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: But I know that there's otherâ€¦ At least a handful or two other communities where for the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: most part people don't drink the drinking water and it's used for all the washing and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: running toilets.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: That's interesting. So it's the idea of rationing water, right? What you would use water for

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: first and then if you had more water you'd get down the list and laundry would maybe be

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: down at the bottom and drinking would be at the top. But you're saying that there's places

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: that have running water where it's almost a little bit upside down. So they haul drinking

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: water and use running, use tap water for not drinking.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Mm-hmm (affirmative). I know that is definitely true with some people and I couldn't tell

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: you how many or anything.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Yeah. Okay. All right. Because a lot of times when we talk about this stuff, this idea of that

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: hauling the water, is actually the limiting. The reason why people don't use as much

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: water. But people might be willing to haul a little bit of water for drinking but not haul all

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: of their water for washing. Okay.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: If you think about it, people in the lower 48 or in the cities are willing to haul big jugs of

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: water from the store because they think it's better. Then turns on the tap at their house.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Let's talk about challenges to infrastructure. You have any good stories about things that

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: broke?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I don't know.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Challenges to look at water infrastructure.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Well, just anytime something breaks or, I don't know. Look at [REDACTED]. That's a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: miracle though that they got a temporary water plant up there so fast. But [REDACTED]

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and that was a pretty big crisis. But even when there's, that was a legit big state of

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: emergency thing. But even a lot of times whenâ€¦ [REDACTED] right now, I think is frozen.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I think they've been frozen for weeks because one little thing didn't work or the heat tape

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: didn't get turned on or whatever and it just turns into this snowball. Into, "Well now we're

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: just frozen until we're not." And it's a lot of times, and I know I was talking to [REDACTED]

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: about this actually with [REDACTED] because I think [REDACTED] is RMW for [REDACTED]

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and he wanted to just go down there and [REDACTED] like, "Well hold on. They need a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: crew. Because if it's just you and one guy working on this, it's going to be a week long,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: two weeks long. Whatever."

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: If they don't gather a crew locally so that you can have 10 people working on this that it

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: can be done in a couple of days, that's what should be happening. But they can get

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: crippled by not having a part, not having a replacement part, not being able to get, maybe

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the remote maintenance worker is going to go out and should go help with something

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: that's technical replacing of a pump or I don't know. But if they can't get out there because

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: of the weather, you guys have seen our weather out here which, everywhere's weather

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: has been crazy. But [REDACTED] had several hundred people stuck at the airport

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [REDACTED] or whatever trying to get out to the villages. And that means no freight was

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: going out for any reason and besides [REDACTED]. But that means grocery stores weren't

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: getting their food and who knows. If they were waiting on an emergency part for the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: water plant, that wasn't going. They've got a million pounds of freight sitting at

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [REDACTED] right now. So there's, I don't know. It's easy for a small thing to really

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: compound and end up crippling the whole system.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Talking about failures, like you said heat tape not getting flipped on. So how would you

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: describe. So some of that is. Someone forgot to flip the tape, right? So some of those are

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: human issues and personnel issues and then some of those. So to what extent is it human

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: resource versus actual infrastructure problems? Like, "Hey, the pipe was just old and it

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: broke because it was a million years old."

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Well, I think that happens too. I just might not be familiar enough with. Yeah. I think a lot

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: of the systems I work with are newer. I'm just thinking about. Because when I had worked

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: as an [REDACTED], we have basically all the villages split up. And so I had [REDACTED] that

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I worked really closely with. For the most part, most of the systems I had had new newer

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: pipes and all that and newer water systems. But I don't know. That definitely happens

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: where there will just be leaks. It's so common to go. I would say it's more uncommon to

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: go into a water plant and there not be a coffee can sitting under a joint, a pipe weld or

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: something where, there's always leaks and I think that has to do with aging systems and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: well, maybe and corrosive water too. But yeah, I don't know. [REDACTED] would beâ€¦ I

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: hope you guys are talking to [REDACTED]. [REDACTED] would be a really good one to talk

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to about these specific issues.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Okay. You work on the people side of things too. So I mean that's, I guess, a good example

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: of okay, there's a leaking joint. Is it because it'sâ€¦ Was that reported? Was it corrected?

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Was there somebody there to be able to do that who had the skill or those sorts of things?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Mm-hmm (affirmative). Well and I think a lot of times if it's a small bucket there and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: they're likeâ€¦ And sometimes they'll ask. I've learned these things over the years. I'll be

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: like, "Well how often do you have to empty that? How fast is this leaking?" And they'll be

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: like, "Once a week or something." And then I'll be like, "Does [REDACTED] know about it?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Or does your RMW know or do you need help with that?" But I think sometimes some of

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the simple things they're pretty good. And the RMWs, that's part of their purpose I think,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: is to teach some of the lower level skills at least as far as making repairs. They don't have

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to go out as often but that's a challenge too because there's turnover.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: There's alwaysâ€¦ There tends to be a lot of turnover and it depends on system to system.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: So [REDACTED] has had the same two water plant operators. [REDACTED]. My whole time

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: here it's been [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] and then [REDACTED], I don't know who's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: working there on any given day. It might be this guy, it might be this other guy. This guy

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: doesn't work there anymore but he still goes and helps out because they can't get anyone

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: else to take it over full time and own it. So turnover is probably one of the bigger problems

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and that contributes to what you were getting at with the human errors. And I think that's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: just because when you've got someone new and their boss is the city administrator or the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: tribal administrator, who probably doesn't know anything about water treatment and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: what they should be doing.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: One of the places I have the biggest problem with this is [REDACTED]. The water plant

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: operator is loved by the city council and he doesn't do anything the city administrator

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: tells him to do, even though that's technically his boss I think. But he's like, "Well, the city

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: council is cool with whatever I do. So I'm never going to get fired." And he does not do

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: any sampling. He does not turn in monthly operator reports. He does zero compliance

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: things. If his boss doesn't care and isn't going to put the thumb down on him and if the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: state's not or if the state just, their messaging is falling on deaf ears, I don't know.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Yeah. Nice.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: And that's a surface water system.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: I know how local government works. How have challenges changed over time? I guess

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: we've talked about two different things. One is the human side in turnover and people

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: and training and then the other thing of just. You said you got the water plants are new

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: or you just are working with villages now that happen to have newer ones?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I think that it's more of that. That most of the villages that I worked closely with just

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: happened to have newer systems. But they still, I don't know. I can think of some that

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: definitely need upgrades and new everything.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Yeah. Has that been happening? How has it changed over time? Have you seen new stuff

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: since you've been there? Improvements?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I have but I think I've heard and I've heard this from [REDACTED] that I know that the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: money is becoming less available and that there are less projects than in the past but

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: again, that's anecdotally. But it seemed, I don't know. I can't tell because. Okay. So,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [REDACTED] water project was [REDACTED] years or something. So it's hard for me. It

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: seems like I've been here for a long time but when a project could take almost as long as

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I've been in here, it's hard for me to judge that I guess if there's less projects now than in

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the past. But there should be or there should be less need. As soon as you tick off the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: places that need a full piped system, there should be less need. But I think as they come

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: around, as you circle around it's. Someday, if they ever get around to piping everywhere,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: it's going to be time to go back around and do big replacement projects for the ones that

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: were done first.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: What about on the human side? Have you seen changes to those challenges?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: No. I don't know. In some places it just depends on who, I think there's a lot of factors on

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: who wants to be the water plant operator and stick around and own that process. Or own

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: running the water plant and doing it on their own without having a lot of other support.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: But it depends. Some communities have a utility coordinator and they have other, I feel

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: like other support staff that help the operators with keeping up on some of that. Maybe

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: some of that compliance stuff. I don't know. I think it's about the same.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Treading water. Okay. So we've alluded to this and it's going to seem a very obvious

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: question to you. Are there particular challenges to operating in arctic environments?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Forget that you're talking to me and pretend that you're talking to someone else.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Okay. I'll just look at [REDACTED].

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: All right.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Well, so yes. I don't know the first one that comes to mind. Wait, a couple of things come

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to mind but so we have to make sure when you're delivering water that it doesn't freeze.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Obviously, first of all. And so in keeping the pipes heated in one way or another and that's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: usually heat tape, electric heat tape or heated glycol. So that's challenge number one, I

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: guess. And then also in water treatment, there's an optimum temperature at which you,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: there's optimum temperature depending on what chemicals you add and all that. And so,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: if you have a too high of temperature, it can help. I haven't been to training for a long

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: time now. But if it's at too high of temperature, the chemicals don't react the right way I

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: guess.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: And so you want to have the water warm so it doesn't freeze but you also don't want to.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: You want to make sure you're not hindering your own treatment process. So that's tricky

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: too because you pull the water out of the ground, it's 32 degrees or so 34 or something

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: very close to freezing. Might be a little higher than that actually but whatever. It's cold

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: but so they have to heat it but then you want to, I don't know, balance that. And that just,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I don't know, it's extreme weather we've been having lately when it's really windy and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: snowy and we get, where we are at most places, it's very flat, so we can get really big

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: snow drifts and things like that can be a problem. But I think probablyâ€¦ What am I

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: forgetting [REDACTED]. You caught me off guard. What else?

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Well, I got some moreâ€¦

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: There's so many things.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: â€¦ related questions but I think that'sâ€¦ I'm not sure if water systems thatâ€¦ So some of the

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: water systems have to move water. Nothing can stop and I think that's a little bit different

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: than some places.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah. it's circulating water. All the systems out here circulate water, even if there'sâ€¦ I

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: think there's usuallyâ€¦ It's they have to either circulate the water or add heat. And I think

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: most of our systems, they might do both. And then they're almostâ€¦ Every system I've

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: ever gone to and surveyed, they all circulate water because there's a question on the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: sanitary survey where it asked about dead ends and they're were all like, "We don't have

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: any. The water it's always moving." But that can cause a problem too on the infrastructure

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: because it wears out pipes faster when you've got more water moving around. So

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [inaudible] with the challenge. And everyone gets all up in arms when their water's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: delayed by a day or two.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: But think about how that works in a village when they're delivering with a hundred-gallon

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: trailer vessel say or 200â€¦ Whatever. They're different but a 100 to 200 gallon vessel on a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: trailer. And they're hauling it around on boardwalk with a four-wheeler with chains on

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the tires trying to keep it from flying off the side and yeah. It gets bad in [REDACTED] and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: people get really bent out of shape about it and they're like, "What are we going to do."

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: One day without water and then, I think it's got to be way worse in the villages and with

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: those small haul systems, they just are terrible anyways. But even some places do snow

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: machines where they can. Like [REDACTED], they're a boardwalk community but they get

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: lots of wind and snow. And everything gets flattened out then they can move a snow

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: machine there.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: They're hauling water with a snow machine. Man, that seems a nightmare. Cool. So I got

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: some other questions related that I will hop back to you but staying on this arctic thing.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Is climate change an issue?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah. I think so.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Not in general, right? But for water infrastructure. Are things changing? Is climate change

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: affecting water?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I think so. Man, I guess I haven't thought about that a lot or not in a while. Well, so most

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: of our villages are having big erosion problems or a lot of villages are. More than has been

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: documented. Most places you can find an area where they're having some erosion, even

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: if it hasn't been on the news or [REDACTED] hasn't been out there. But [REDACTED], their

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: school is getting demoâ€™d through an emergency order or something through the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: governor. I think. And the water plant is not very far away from there, which is their

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: primaryâ€¦ [REDACTED] is lucky in that they have two wells. One is the community water

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: system well. That's the one that's going to go in the water first. And then the second one

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: is just tied to their washeteria which me and [REDACTED] have talked about this. He's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: talked to the community about it I think and their plan is to just switch the primary water

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: source to the washeteria well and system.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: So they are lucky in the fact that they do have a backup but that eventually will need toâ€¦

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I don't know. They're going to be leapfrogging away from the river or they're calling it a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: slow retreat away from the river bank because it's just eroding away. So I think that's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: climate change. The river bank's not being, but also I think it's part of a natural process.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: But the banks not being able to hold where they already anymore because the permafrost

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: isn't staying frozen long enough in the air.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: You talked about people seeking traditional sources of water. Are the traditional sources

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: of water changing because of melting permafrost or other? Do of any of examples of that?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I don't. I could imagine that there would be some changes in that but I don't know any.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: I'm curious about that one because that's one of the hypotheses, is that well, the

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: groundwater might be changing or the surface water might be changing or things that

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: have. Things might be melting and kicking up into that. But I don't know any.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Okay. I got a quick one for you. You live in [REDACTED]. Somebody's moving to

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: [REDACTED]. They say, "Hey, heard water delivery is crazy. Looking to buy a house." What

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: would you tell someone coming there new that had heard about some of the water stuff

Speaker: Interviewer 1
