Text: That they need that in order to be successful. Man, I'm trying toâ€¦ I don't know. I'm trying

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to think ofâ€¦ Because even in [REDACTED], they're our golden child but even they have

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: problems out there. One time I think I was on my way out there and I started talking to

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: this guy at the airport and he was like, "Where are you going?" So I mentioned

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [REDACTED] and he was like, "I just came from out there." He is like, "Don't drink the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: water. They add bleach to it." And I was like, "What?" I didn't evenâ€¦ I think I walked away

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: because I was like, "Yes. Okay. Everybody does, I guess technically. But I don't know." So

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: it's difficult.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: We just heard the water in [REDACTED] was very good. We just had aâ€¦ We got glowing

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: reviews of the [REDACTED] water. It was better than [REDACTED].

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah. But even some of our best operators they don't deal very well with confrontation

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: from the community. I can think of where I've been involved before in one of the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: communities where somebody overheardâ€¦ It was all about the CCR, the Consumer

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Confidence Report that is required, gets sent out and done every year. And that someone

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: was talking and overheard contaminants or something. And then that was like all these

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: rumors start going around. And then the water plant operator wanted me to deal with it.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: And I wasâ€¦ But it was just a rumor. I don'tâ€¦ I'm like, "You know your wire. You need to

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: address this." I'm like, "You know you do your testing, you have your CCR, you know you

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: don't have violations." You know what I mean? And so sometimes we've got that whereâ€¦

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I can think of a few times where we've had that come up. Where the operatorâ€¦ Peopleâ€¦

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: The community is outraged at the operator because they think something and it's not

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: true at all. You should never have the community trying to burn the water plant operator

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: at the stake. Gosh. No wonder they quit.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Yeah. Well, that's interesting because that's probably not part of the water treatment

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: certification is dealing with the public. I'm guessing there's probably not any piece to

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: public relations or advocating orâ€¦

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: They talk about public notifications.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Right. So it's a letter that says, "Your water was bad this week. Oops." That's what we do

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: in [REDACTED]. I got one of those.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Uh-huh (affirmative). Yeah.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Well [REDACTED], we're pushing time. What do youâ€¦? Is there anyâ€¦ You got any burning

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: questions here that we should hit on?

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: I don't think so. I was just looking throughâ€¦ Yeah. I guess anyâ€¦ Do you have any other

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: thoughts that you want to add orâ€¦?

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: What should we have asked you?

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Yeah. Is something that we didn't ask you that we should have?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I don't know. No, I don't know. I think you guys asked me a lot. I wish I had better answers

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: for some of your questions. But no, I donâ€™t know. This was fun. [REDACTED]

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Okeydokey. Cool, all right. So just some background, kind of went over the fact

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: here, so you moved to [REDACTED], but how long were you in [REDACTED]?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I was in [REDACTED] a minimum of [REDACTED] years straight, total. And at the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: end of that time, I was the [REDACTED], before I left there. So I spent some time

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: in the villages early on, but mostly it's all been in [REDACTED].

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Oh, okay. Well, so, see, I didn't know that. Yeah, walk us through, where were

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: you, or what brought you to the region?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Well, I mean, we had a bad economy crash in [REDACTED], this is where I've spent

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: my whole life. My first plane ride was to Alaska when that happened. So

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: everybody was losing their jobs, and I saw an ad in the paper for a $10,000

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: completion bonus of a contract for a [REDACTED], and I just kind of fell in love

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: with the state and ended up in [REDACTED].

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Okay. You were in the village too, though?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I did, I was a [REDACTED] in [REDACTED], I spent about [REDACTED] years out

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: there. And there's a little bit different, they have a piped system which I don't

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: know much about, they use vacuum for their waste. But yeah, it's a little bit

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: different than what [REDACTED] has going on.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Yeah, I think [REDACTED] has one of those weird vacuum toilets, right?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: They do. Yeah, so like there'll be a leak, and they'll go around to everybody's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: house trying to figure out where the leak's at. It's obnoxious, but it works, for the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: most part.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Yeah, okay. Well I didn't know you were out in [REDACTED], so the questions are

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: kind of based on your experience, and so if you have different experience or ideas

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: of how things were different in [REDACTED] than in [REDACTED], that's fine, just

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: let us know. We're looking for kind of a region-wide perspective. I contacted you

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: because I knew about the [REDACTED] in [REDACTED], but sounds like you've got

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: some other relevant experience as a user, if nothing else, in other places.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Sure. Right, and my wife's from [REDACTED], which has amazing water, and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: they've had infrastructure for water and sewer for years, now. And I might be

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: able to give you some insight there as well.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Okay, sounds good. Let's see, so you touched on this a little bit. Can you tell me

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: about your educational and professional background? So like schooling, or how

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: you got educated to do the things that you did with water infrastructure?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Well, as far as water infrastructure, there wasn't much schooling other than on

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the job. My highest level of education is [REDACTED], and I've been in

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: construction most of my life. Actually, I'm a plumber by trade. But Alaska seems

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to be a lot different, being mainly boilers.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: When I took the job in [REDACTED] as a foreman, before that I was a water truck

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: driver. I was also working in the mechanics department for a little bit. And you

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: learn a lot of rules and regulations just by that. So as a foreman, I was mostly

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: dealing with the logistical side of things, not so much like lagoons or anything else.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Yeah, yeah. Well, this is actually, that'sâ€¦ This is great. You're the guy we want to

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: talk to, I think.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Okay.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: All right. So some of these questions, if you feel like they're repeats, don't worry

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: about it. I'm not trying to make you say the same thing over and over again, but

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: if you feel like there's anything you have to addâ€¦ So is that all the ways that

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: you've worked with water infrastructure? You were a driver, like so [REDACTED],

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: like, has drove a big delivery truck, right? And-

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Right. 3500-gallon water trucks. And with those, you just go house to house.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: There's hookups plumbed outside for each house, and you hook your nozzle up

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to it and you just pump away. And currently how the system works is you have

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: tanks inside the house, and they could be multiple, plastic or single steel or

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: whatever they want. And when it gets to the point where it's full, there's an

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: overflow pipe where the water starts to pour out of that, which signals the driver

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to stop pumping.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Unless the overflow's frozen, right?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Well, yes, yes, yes. Yeah. That happens a lot. So that's actually a huge cost issue,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and it's a real big pain. And it's like, not only does it cost a lot of money to the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: homeowner, but it also slows down services. So right now the way it's set up in

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the city of [REDACTED]â€¦ And it's hard to find talent. Maybe not even, talent's not

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the word, just people with CDLs. We're at the point now where you could have

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: your CDL one day and we're going to put you in a $250,000 truck and get you out

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: there working, because we need it. It's essential.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: But like I said, back to it, it's very expensive. Replacing pipes, repairing flood

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: damage. Most of the time the city of [REDACTED] not going to help you with the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: cost of that. The verbiage in the contract sets them up to be pretty safe, for the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: most part, being that if your pipes are frozen, we're not liable.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Secondly to that is, a lot of the drivers spend some time trying to clear these out.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: They actually do have a heart, where they could just walk away. They spend some

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: time, which slows them down in getting to the next house. The average driver

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: works between 8 and 10 hours a day on good times, and 14 to 15 for wintertime,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: just because it's slower to drive, the driveways are icy, the pipes are icy. And

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: unfortunately, being an essential service and government, and due to the size of

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: our town, [REDACTED], we're not subject to federal regulations for the FMCSA, I

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: believe it is. Basically the Federal Motor Carrier's Association rules and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: regulations that dictate the amount of hours that a trucker can drive. Where

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: normally it would be seven days, 70 hours, or eight days, 80 hours, or mileage.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: We're not subject to that in [REDACTED], so we just basically run our drivers to

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the point where they don't want to work anymore, and then we try to find more.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: And just to build on that piece a little bit about drivers having a heart or trying to

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: clear out the pipe, another thing that I've heard too is, or I've experienced,

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: actually, is that experienced drivers know about how much water should be going

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: into a house. Sometimes the new ones don't. And so there's a difference between

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: having your house flooded with an extra 50 gallons of water and having your

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: house flooded with an extra 500 gallons of water. I've been on both of those. So

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: that [crosstalk]-

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: That's true. In fact, we just had a guy retire, [REDACTED], he's been with the city

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: for [REDACTED] years. And he knows, he'll learn. He knows, once a family stay in

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: their house for a very long time, and he knows every time he goes there, say, he

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: puts about 300 gallons in. So he knows that if it takes about 300 gallons, maybe

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: 400, he's timing it. The pumps have variable speed, but he can get pretty close.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: And so if he starts to go over that, he's thinking, "Wait a minute, we might have

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: an issue." So that's whatâ€¦ He's not going to flood you. He might shortchange you,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: but he's not going to flood you.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Also a guy that, with that much experience could just listen to the tone that the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: overflow pipe is putting out, and can get a sense of how full the tanks are. But

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: these new guys, they just don't have that skill. And they know it's an 800-gallon

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: tank, and they're not going to stop and think about anything until they get to

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: 1000. And it could've been overflowing from 600.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Can you walk us through kind of your day as a foreman?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Sure. So a foreman, you try not to work when you're not working, but there's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: parts of it that you are keeping in mind, like whether, as you drive to work, you're

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: taking account of the road conditions. You're thinking about what you want to do

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: for a safety meeting, the subjects you want to cross. You're thinking about things

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: you need to address, whether it's safety-related or not, or if there's tension in the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: group and you want to just build your team up a little bit that day.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: So you get to the office. And your route's already together, but you're starting to

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: kind of see what you want to do. Like only once in the five years have I ever

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: canceled a route in the morning, and it was just way too icy and dangerous. But

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: basically you conduct your morning, you helped your guys do the walk-arounds.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: You deal with any issues, and there's always issues, there's always questions, and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: you got to be there for that. You assign trucks, help the new guys. Basically after

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: you get your guys out the door in the morning, you start going through customer

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: requests and extra calls, and you start just setting a pace for your day, getting

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: kind of an idea of what it looks like. Do I have enough drivers to cover my routes,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: do I need to communicate that with the office? I could choose to say no extra

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: calls, meaning that if you used up all your water before your next scheduled

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: service, and you want more, I might just tell you you're not getting it. Which

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: means you're toilet's going to fill up, unless you haul your own water. You're not

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: going to take a shower, you're not going to wash the dishes. And like I said, that

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: all is based on what I got going on that day.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Like capacity, you mean?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Right. So 10 routes a day, most of this last year, I should say 12 months, because

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: we're kind of in-between years, I've had about nine drivers a day, so, that's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: splitting a route. So if I have nine drivers with 10 routes a day, and I got one guy

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: calls in sick, now I really have an issue. So now, like I said, on a normal, good day,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: my guys are working eight to 10 hours. Well now, we just bumped them up, now

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: we're doing 14 hours. And I'm not going to ask these guys to do extra calls. I want

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to get my commitment for this first. It's unfortunate, but the reasoning is the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: customer really needs toâ€¦ They live here, they know how it's going, they need to

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: manage the water a little better. It's not a very good excuse, it's kind ofâ€¦ I don't

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: know the word [inaudible]. It's a poor excuse. I wish we were allowed to tell

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: people that.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: And to follow up with that a little bit, how often do you get those calls with people

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: asking you to come early?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Every day. Multiple.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Okay.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: So pretty often.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah. Anywhere from five to 25 requests. Especially when it's summertime and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: you got tugboats that want water.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Yeah. And so when you're in that situation, would you say that you're mainly

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: limited byâ€¦ It's typically having the available drivers, not really the equipment or

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: water source issues or anything like that?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: It used to be that trucks were a factor. It used to be that, the city allowed their

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: fleet to get so old that when they would break they would have a hard time

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: finding replacement parts. And we would literally have drivers and no trucks. City

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: made a very good decision on upgrading their fleet, which has eliminated that

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: part of our issue. Never have I had an issue with not enough water. Even during

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: large fires, we've always had enough water to service our community. So yeah, at

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: this point mainly it is just the drivers, being able to get ahold of them. And there's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: a lot of reasons why we don't get drivers. So yeah, mostly just drivers at this point.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: You have to just draw a line, you literally only have so much to work with. You

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: have a noise ordinance that starts at 10:00 PM, and we still have guys working

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: sometimes to 11:00 and 12:00 midnight just to get it done, just out of sense of

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: duty. You don't even ask these guys to work that much, there's just a sense of

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: duty to their community that they want to get that finished.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Wow.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: So, when people call, I mean, they call you, like you talk to people?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Yeah. And [crosstalk]-

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: A lot of times. I try not to be the initial point of contact. I hired an assistant, which

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: has been the first time since many foremen before me. Also they're encouraged

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to go through the office. But a lot of times they really don't have the up-to-date

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: information, and they can't really answer questions of people that are pretty

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: upset. I was pretty good at that, so I ended up talking to a few of them.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Can you tell us a little bit about talking to people, talking to people about water

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: systems, explaining how things work? I mean, do you ever do thatâ€¦ I guess it's

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: probably one at a time, not so much public, but is that, that's part of your job too

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: I guess, huh?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: It is. And I've spoken to people, like to [REDACTED], people trying to get loans for

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: a house in [REDACTED], and they have no idea how it works out here. Newcomers

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to [REDACTED], physically here, I'll go out and I'll walk through everything with

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: them. We'll do some problem-solving with people who've been there their whole

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: lives, but their sewer tank was buried, and they don't know how big it is, or if it's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: leaking or if it's not. Mostly my interactions were with frustrated people who pay

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: a lot of money for the service and are now not getting it. Because unfortunately

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: it wasn't just, "I can't give you extra service," there's a lot of times where I can't

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: give you the service that you're owed. We have a lot of upset people just for that.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Did you have any follow-ups on that, [REDACTED]? All right. So how is drinking

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: water provided? So you've got the trucks, the other half of thatâ€¦ Like walk us

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: from the ground, how does water get to people's tap?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I'll do my best on that. I was never part of that system. That system is separate

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: from what I did. That's a whole nother thing. Now, you have to be a certified

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: water plant operator, and those names are public knowledge. For example, you

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: could go look up [REDACTED] in the public Alaska registry as a water plant

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: operator. What they do is, I can't say exactly where, but they pick up

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: groundwater, I think there's some kind of well out there by [REDACTED].

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: There's-

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah, [REDACTED]. They pick up the water that's non-potable, they add chlorine

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and some other chemicals, they do multiple tests on it every hour, and they mix

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the contents and they adjust the pH, and when they have an acceptable solution

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: it goes into a holding tank where that is what's provided through the pipes and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to the water trucks. But basically it starts as groundwater. You're not going to get

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: water, we don't ship water in or anything like that. It's just out of the ground.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: How much of the water is through your shop and how much is through the pipes?

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Like what's the split look like? Or how many houses do you do, I guess?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Well, I figured out my last count that I do about [REDACTED] stops a week, with

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [REDACTED] trucks. [REDACTED] water, and then I do it again with [REDACTED]

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: sewer. But those, some of those are repeat, some of those are not. So, I mean,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: you're familiar with the area, others listening might not be. But basically, you got

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: all of [REDACTED], all of [REDACTED], you have all of [REDACTED]. Then you got

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [REDACTED]. So what that really means leftover is [REDACTED] and [REDACTED].

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: So I'd say two thirds of the water is delivered in [REDACTED]. So that's with, what,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: between [REDACTED] people?

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: I have just a question that's not on the list, but I'm just curious based on your

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: experience. I was on piped water, or I was on hauled water and then I moved to

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: piped water. If you had to pick, or if you knew somebody, if [REDACTED] here was

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: moving to [REDACTED], what would you tell her about piped versus hauled

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: water?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I would say go hauled water. Hauled, hauled, hauled, hauled. Because the quality

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: is better, you're not relying on the age or condition of the pipes that are down

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the line. Basically all that stuff that you cannot control in between the houses, the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: main water supply line. Also, you can have a freeze down the line that's somebody

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: else's fault that impacts your house. Whereas hauled water, you're completely

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: on your own system. It's up to you to keep your pipes warm, and once you've got

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: a good system in place, you really never got to worry about it. And if you run out

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: of water, you could always go and fill your own, you can get some big garbage

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: cans and fill it up for quarters, and bring it to your house and pump it into your

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: tank. Whereas if you're on pipe systemâ€¦ The only reason I say the quality of the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: pipe is a lot of people have yellow water. There's a tinge to it. It's just from the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: old days, I don't know if it's all poly pipe or if there's some metal pipe in there

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: somewhere.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: I think [REDACTED] has got iron pipes, yeah.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah, see, we don't need that much iron in our diet.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: You talked a little bit about this, do you have any other sort of anecdotes about a

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: challenge in local water infrastructure? You got any good stories for us about

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: something breaking or having to solve a problem? Maybe? No?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: We continue to grow with new technology and better design of our trucks. But

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: we've come a long way. Water and sewer used to be done with giant wooden

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: barrels on the back of flatbed pickups. We used to fill garbage cans. They used to

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: have these giant wooden barrels, and they would use a gas-powered Honda

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: pump, trash pump, and they would stick one into the barrel and then they'd fill

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: up your garbage can on your deck, and away we went. They used to take the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: buckets out of your living room and walk out, try not to spill any on your living

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: room floor, and dump it into that other barrel. But these winters, when we're

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: driving truck, you got to drive out to [REDACTED].

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I guess one challenge I always thought was kind of cool was, it was a pain in the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: butt, but it was unique to working so hard in the cold conditions is that you would

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: have to stop every mile or so and pump some water, because your entire line will

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: freeze. In the old days they used to stick the nozzle up by the exhaust stack, which

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I thought was horrible. That was before my time. But you would literally have an

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: inch and a quarter line that's 100 feet long frozen, and you would have to come

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to the shop three, four times a day just to thaw out to go back out to do your

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: route. It's because of things like that, and it's not really an anecdote or anything,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: but it's something that I thought was special, is that it takes some of the toughest

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: men and women with the greatest amount of fortitude to continually get up and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: do this job every day. It's absolutely brutal, it's freezing. You're literally standing

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: out in the wind pumping water in -60 windchill up on a hill in [REDACTED] while

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: you're so frozen you need to break the ice to bend your knee.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: And then you get in a truck for five minutes, you're already parked at the next

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: house, and you do it again. And you do that for 14 hours a day. I always admire

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the crew that works on water and sewer for that.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Yeah. But sounds like it makes it hard to hire sometimes, too, huh?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Well, it's, yeah, people know about it. They're scared of the work. A lot of young

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: guys I get that can't handle it. It's the old-timers that stay, it's the old veterans.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: My crewâ€¦ Or it's not my crew anymore, I guess, but my solid guys that work year-

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: round that we've never had a problem with, that we always depended on. The

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: only reason [REDACTED] has had the service they've had is because of men and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: women that were in their 50s. These are all people getting ready to retire. I've

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: hired big, strong kids, and they make it a week or two. And we continually go

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: through them like that.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: So, there was a question here about seasonality of challenges, of infrastructure

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: challenges. So it sounds like winter is the tough season.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah. Yeah, I think the guys would rather swat mosquitoes than freeze.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: And you kind of hit on this a little bit about how challenges have changed over

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: time, so it'sâ€¦ Would you say that things have trended, trending better? Things

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: are getting better?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: They're trending better as far as SOP and mechanical. We're still in the same rut

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: as far as consistently hiring employees to drive these trucks. There's too much

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: competition, there's a bad name for the work, there's too many hours.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [REDACTED] is a society where the dollar is not the value system. I mean, sure,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: for some, we all have to make the money. But what's really valuable in

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [REDACTED] is hunting, and sharing your food, and subsistence, and family. And

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: that's what makes the place so special. So now you're asking these Native men

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and women to come drive for me and I'm telling them, "Nope, you can't moose

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: hunt, I don't got enough guys. Nope, you can't go fishing." That's a big issue. So

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: you got to get guys from out of town, because they go for [REDACTED], they go

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: for the other fueling guys. They're making more with those companies starting

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: out, they get two weeks on, two weeks off. Or they leave their family and they

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: come here to [REDACTED] and work, and they get a bunk house to stay in.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Here, you want to work for us, you better get a house, you better pay 1800 a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: month. So who's going to leave [REDACTED], and it's beautiful here, and who's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: going to leave this to go be in [REDACTED] and pay exorbitant amounts for rent

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and food for less possibilities in their life? So yeah, it is trending better in certain

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: ways, but you have one major issue that doesn't seem to be worked on. And I've

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: begged and I've pleaded for it to the point where I just got red-faced and gave up.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: What would help with that?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: See, I've always been told eight different ways that I'm wrong, but I believe that

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: a bunkhouse and a two weeks rotational shift would be hugely beneficial. I've

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: been told that, "If you're going to provide them with housing, I want housing.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Even though I live here." Or, "I want extra money in my paycheck." The city

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: manager says the union won't allow it; the union says the city manager won't

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: allow it. The public works director said, "That's not going to happen." I don't know

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: any other way but to model ourselves after a more successful company, and I

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: mean successful in staffing, not monetarily, but staffing. These other guys are full,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and that's the one thing they all have in common is a bunkhouse. You come here,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: you work for two weeks, that's common in Alaska. You can go out to the slope all

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the time; you see guys doing that year after year. They're cool with that. Go spend

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: some time with their family, come back here, work them to death. That's what

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: they want to do, work them 12, 15 hours a day. Maybe you can keep the locals

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: on a more regular schedule because you got these outsiders coming in to pick up

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the slack, now you can have everybody going out and doing subsistence.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Changing subject a little bit, are there any water quality challenges that you have?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Not that I'm aware of. Like I said, yellow water. I mean, I know they do their tests,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I know they say that they're safe, but I don't know, the quality, I don't know. I

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: don't know what you're going to do in [REDACTED] to improve quality. I know

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: that [REDACTED] and [REDACTED]â€¦ Well, let's just leave [REDACTED] out of that,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [REDACTED] is, wow, their water quality is amazing. And I don't know how they're

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: doing it, but you could drink it straight out the tap, it's cold as ice, it tastes so

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: pure, and it's the best water I've literally had in my life. So if [REDACTED] could

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: somehow model themselves after [REDACTED] that would probably be an

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: improvement.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: So, some of these we hit on already, challenges due to arctic conditions, right?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Times where you've had to be creative responding to challenges, and what you

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: would need, what would help. So I want to drill down on that one a little bit, when

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: you're talking about two on two off, I mean that also would be a package with

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: basically flying people in, right? I mean, it probably wouldn't be locals.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Right.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: It would be more like [REDACTED] does with the bunkhouse. Or [REDACTED],

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: pilots.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah, we'll probably have to be more like what the police are doing. I think they

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: pay their own airfare, but the difference with those guys is that they work

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: together. They're all mainly from [REDACTED], and they kind of know each other

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: from the departments down there and they split rent. So it's very cheap out here,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and you'll get two shifts, three or four guys splitting the one apartment. So it's a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: little bit easier for them. But you're not going to find CDL drivers to actively do

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: that, you would have to have somebody that organizes that.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: So, I don't know if this isâ€¦ Have you seen any impact of changing climate on the

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: ability to deliver water and water infrastructure?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Well, I don't knowâ€¦ We say we've noticed the changing climate, I mean, seems

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: that the winters are growing to be more snow and less ice, lately, which does help

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: with traction on the vehicles. Other than that, I couldn't really comment on it. The

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: drawback with too much snow, of course, if you can't see the driveways, you get

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: stuck a lot. But at least you're not sliding off the road.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: We had, a couple years ago we had that year where like, it rained the entire

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: month of February, and the roads were disgusting.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yes.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: That was a mess.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: That was that one time that I canceled a route right away, that was the one and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: only time was during that period.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: It was out in [inaudible].

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Yeah. But I guess in general, kind of warmer, wetter weather is better than colder,

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: colder weather. Colder weather.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: It is for human beings and mechanical, for sure.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Yeah. So maybe you answered this already, but the water infrastructure challenge

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: that you think is most important to fix, and if you could wave a magic wand and

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: fix it, sounds like it's people, right?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: If I had a magic wand? I mean, sure, more people if I wanted to fix the current

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: conditions. But honestly, I would build another water plant, and I would pipe the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: entire city, and then I would work on replacing all of the oldest pipe.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: You think pipes are-

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: And then try to keep-

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Pipes are kind of the future, or the ideal goal?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: That's the ideal goal. If I had a magic wand, trucks need to go away. They do. I

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: mean, that's just a whole nother cost for the community. I mean, it's good for

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: jobs, but they can pipe everythingâ€¦ You need to hire, take a lot of these water

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: truck drivers and put them on a different department to work on the pipes.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: So, we talked a little bit about, so system failures from your end I guess would be

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: times where you couldn't deliver water, or interruptions in services. You

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: mentioned that, how often does that happen? I mean, I guess if I was a customer,

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: and I got water delivered once a week, or was supposed to, how often would I

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: not get my water when I was supposed to?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Well, we try to keep in mind who was last, I don't know, skipped, I guess,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: intentionally skipped. We try to rotate the affected people. So with that in mind,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: it just depends on the season and the amount of drivers I have. It could be at any

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: point of the year, they could be in any season. It'd be hard to put a number on

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: that. I would say no more than four times a year, which would be, as a whole, as

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: a community, say, [REDACTED], skipped, a year. So I'd say no more than four

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: times a year. So when I say, if I miss like, say, [REDACTED], say it's route four, I tell

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the route four guy to go help the route five guy, and then I have him cascade

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: down the other routes to finish everybody off, we would make that a first priority

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: the next morning. But to answer your question, I would say no more than four

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: times a year in any one spot.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Knowing that stuff, is there a priority for planning? Like what's the planning

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: process for the future, for infrastructure?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Pipe everybody. That way. Yeah. [REDACTED] Yeah, I know they want to be on a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: water pipe. And I know that there's some other issues that they deal with right

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: now with [REDACTED] that they're working on. We need to have so many

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: thousands of gallons on reserve for the school, as well as a higher capacity for

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: what [REDACTED] is expected to use. Which is why I say another, a plant would

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: be nice, another water filtration plant. Even right now if we had that, just for the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: trucks out in [REDACTED], that would be a life-saver. Because it's a 45 minute to

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: one hour round-trip every time the trucks go empty. So if you can imagine, like in

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [REDACTED] you have 45 houses to do on your route, you could do between four

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and six, four and seven houses, but you got an hour round-trip to refill. I know

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: that's a little off-subject right now, but the future is definitely piped.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Yeah, okay. Well, I'm going to roll through a couple of questions pretty quickly,

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: because I think you've already answered them, but if there's anything that jumps

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: out at you that you want to add to it, please do.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Can I add a quick follow-up question too on that? So you kind of said, right, the

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: future is putting in piped everywhere. What are some kind of barriers for that

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: happening? Is it funding, is it workforce considerations, kind of things like that?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I think it's always funding, it's always going to be funding. And I know we can find

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: it. Yeah, so I don't know. And I also heard some rumor that there's some issues

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: with the Arctic Pipe that's being used not being as available as it used to be.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Apparently there's not too many people that make it. But I don't know, that's all

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I've heard. I don't know if it's true or not.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Okay, yeah.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Pivoting a little bit towards management, because you supervise people as a

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: foreman, right? So there's some questions about what management challenges

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: you face, what workforce challenges you face, how you respond to these

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: challenges, what you would need to better respond to these challenges. So those,

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: I mean, I feel like you've kind of covered those, if there's any other thing that

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: jumps out at you to add.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Sure. Took me a few years to realize it. At first I considered more what my city

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: administration wanted of me, which was to crack the whip, push, squeeze them

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: for all they were worth, just whip, whip, whip. And I grew up learning that a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: management, a boss shouldn't ask you to do things that they wouldn't do. So the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: hours they worked, the things they did, it began to be something that I wouldn't

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: do.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: So what I did was I emphasized more on my crew's happiness than I did the job. I

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: realize that my guys have a sense of community that no matter what I said to

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: them, even if they were to be disobedient, it would be to get the job done. So,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: what I did is we had this saying that you work to live, you do not live to work. And

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: that means that this job should not be taking away from your happiness in life. So

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: we made every effort to make sure that these guys had time off, even if we really,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: really needed them. Sometimes guys would be wanting to work and you would

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: tell them no, because it's their day off, and you know they need rest. We started

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: caring more about the employee, and what happened was that you would have

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: less internal conflict between the employees, you would have better production

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: from the employees, and overall more positive attitude out of them.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: And you only employed people with CDL?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yep.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Okay. So you basically, that's the group of people that you're trying to hire. Did

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: you ever hire somebody who said they were going to get a CDL, or was it just,

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: "Once you get a CDL, come find me."

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: We have, we have. In fact, there's been a loose system on that, we've actually

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: hired people before they've even had their permits, just with the intent. We pay

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: them full wages, we teach them how to drive, we get them their permit, and then

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: we actually pay for them to get their CDL, take the test. We've actually sent

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: people down to driving schools down this way towards [REDACTED], and had

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: them do that. We've had some guys fail, we've had some guys kind of flake off,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: which has burdened the system a little bit. Because it's expensive, it's about

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: $6,000 for school. But now I think where we last left off was if you show us the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: initiative, that you studied, and that you've got your permit, then we will hire you.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: And then we give you a time period.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Can they work with a permit? I mean is that?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: They cannot drive our vehicles, but they could ride in the right seat and learn the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: job. They can see how it's done, we put them with an experienced driver. We'll

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: also give them time with like one of the streets and roads guys who would give

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: them some drive time in certain situations.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: And they can learn how the pumps work and all that, the other part, right?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah. In the meantime, they're getting trained up for what they're going to be

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: doing, but also for their CDL.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Okay.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: And a paycheck.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: And kind of a follow-up on that, can you walk us through some of that initial

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: training? So, say someone's just started, they have their license. How do they get

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: trained in terms of kind of actually working the pumps and the whole system? Is

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: it just from kind of someone who's been there longer, is it more formalized

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: training?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: It's not complicated. So, the biggest part is every morning you do a walk-around.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: So the experienced driver will show you the walk-around, there's, I know, loosely,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: there's about 45 places that you search on the truck to make sure it's safe to drive.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: And you do that every morning. You either, you're told to do it, or you're

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: explained how to do it. As far as the pumps go, 40 to 60 houses a day, you see it

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: turned on and turned off that many times every single day, you'll pick it up.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: [REDACTED] Well, I have a question. So do you feel like, is the CDL, is that useful

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: information? Or is that kind of jumping through hoops? Like could you do on the

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: job training, could you teach that stuff? Or is the time people spend doing CDL, is

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: that really very valuable for the job they're going to be doing?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: It depends. I mean, I honestly, I prefer to teach guys myself when they come in

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: with an idea. Unless they're really experienced, and if they come in kind of

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: halfway experienced, that could be dangerous if they have too much confidence.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: There's no replacement for experience. So I guess with that said, if you don't have

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: a lot of it, I'd prefer to train them. But it doesn't take a lot to get your license.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Do you think your situation would beâ€¦ I mean, you're only hiring people with a

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: CDL because you have to, right? So if we could wave a wand and say that's not

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: the rule anymore, you can hire whoever you want, would you still hire people

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: with a CDL, or would you, how would you value that?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: No, no. I would hire anybody that can drive, man. And that's how it used to be.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: [REDACTED] used to be where you could, it was off-highway, it was exempt. And

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: we had full crews, all the time. This was back when they had 25 people, they had

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: 25 drivers for less than a city. Could you imagine? These guys were getting done

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: in six hours. They would all drive back to the shop and have coffee breaks, and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: then they'd go back on the road, finish the route, and clean the shop for a couple

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: hours. Now there's only a roster of 15 positions allowed. [REDACTED] Yeah, so

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: now there's only 15 positions, and it's so tight, and we still can't fill those. And

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: that's why we lost them, is because they got tired of allocating money every year

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: for positions that would never be filled. Take away that CDL garbage, it's just a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: piece of paper, and we would have no problems with these trucks.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: What changed?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: The DOT. They said, "Well, hold on, it's a city, that's a highway right there, you

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: can't be driving these trucks on a highway without a CDL in the middle of

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: nowhere." It's ridiculous, man. And I think everybody understands that there'sâ€¦

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: A certificate doesn't change anything. You have a knack for it, you can do it or you

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: can't do it. I mean, I suppose if you're a microbiologist, yeah, you should probably

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: go to school. But this isn't that, this is driving a large Subaru. You just turn a little

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: later. There's some things you got to learn about air breaks. Okay, we can teach

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: that.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: You said there's been some people you've tried to put through training and

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: they've kind of flaked out or whatever. Are there challengesâ€¦ You said it wasn't

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: that hard to get a CDL. Have you had people that just kind of can't do it? I mean,

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: has that been a barrier? And if it is a barrier, is it a barrier that people can't do it,

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: or because they just kind of don't want to?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: They don't want to. It's the whole you can lead a horse to water thing. They're

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: just not ambitious.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: But not, it's not an issue of justâ€¦ I don't know the test, so I'm speaking out of

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: ignorance here, but-

Speaker: Interviewee

Text: Very good. So, next question is about water quality. Do you face water quality challenges?

Text: Yeah, definitely, we have intermittent supply issues. I'm thinking of a couple of

Speaker: Interviewee

Text: water systems, like [REDACTED] is an example that comes to mind. So they have to

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: remove their river intake entirely during freeze-up each spring and during break-up each

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: fall. So we have these awkward seasons during break-up and freeze-up where we have

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: virtually no supply because we had to pull the supply to switch over to the next season.

Text: Interesting.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: We also have, not that many anymore, when I started we had a lot of them, but systems

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: I [crosstalk].

Text: Where we pump water seasonally, right? So we pump water in the unfrozen part of the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: year, we fill up a giant water tank, and we try to make that last as long as we can. But

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: there's not that many of those systems that rely entirely on fill-and-draw any longer.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Okay.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: So yes, lots of intermittent challenges.

Text: Yeah. What's up with water quality? Remind me of the question.

Text: how we literally have to pull it out in the freeze-up, and break-up is what we callâ€¦ Sorry,

Text: what it sounds like if you're imagining an icy river. So, yeah. Our source water changes

Text: whatever reason, or other changes that need to be made, I don't always feel that the

Text: positions to work with a bunch of 50 or so public water systems. I really can't say enough

Text: about that program. I feel like it's just such a success, for so many reasons, but that is one

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: of the things that exists within that black hole that I mentioned between the state

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: systems, and the local operations teams. So I think programs like that have really

Text: providers. Go ahead.

Text: Yeah, can you expand a little bit, when you're talking about this knowledge gap, of why

Speaker: Interviewee

Text: Okay.

Text: If we were going to look at the disconnect or the gap between operators and folks that

Text: are out in the field and the DEC and the state, do youâ€¦ I mean, you used the word

Text: emergencies. We're just addressing emergencies, day in, day out. So sometimes taking

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: lead and copper samples is not the emergency fire that the operator is going to put time

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: in, on his two hours a day that he may or may not get paid for.

Text: Okay. Can you describe a time when you've had to be creative responding to a challenge?

Text: As it pertains to solving a water quality or infrastructure problem. How's that?

Text: Okay. Yeah. So I think playing the long game, [REDACTED] noticed years ago is that it

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: wasn't just about the operations. We were not even getting to the point with some of our

Speaker: Interviewee

Speaker: Interviewee

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: And these are the few remaining communities in Alaska that don't have sewer

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: infrastructure, right? So you would think that they would be competitive for getting water

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: plants, because we have homes with no running water. But because the managerial

Speaker: Interviewee

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: were just not scoring out high enough to really qualify for that funding to even get a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: project.

Text: So I think one of the creative solutions over the years that I can think of is focusing on

Text: you want to get a new water system in a community, you would therefore have to go

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: upstream and work on resolving and building some of the managerial capacity so that

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: that can happen a few years later.

Text: Yeah. Yep, absolutely. Yeah. So, like helping the community entity enact good business

Text: practices so that they can show they have the revenue, and they have accountants on file,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and they have been to manager training. That is all before we even get to the operations

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: point.

Text: Great. You touched on this before. What challenges are unique to your utility due to the

Text: reason. Either there's no easy water source or there's no good way to put in a distribution

Text: However, in the other communities, I would just say it's hard to run a functional water

Text: infrastructure system? Or maybe a better question is, does it?

Text: So we have this above-ground HDPE Arctic pipe, and we have posts and pads that the

Text: pipes are built on. And those, we're doing what we call jacking, which I'm sure is not a

Text: specific term, but that's the only thing the guys ever call it. And they're just like, the

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: permafrost isâ€¦ They're just going up and moving all around. So it's hard to run a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: distribution system, HDPEâ€¦ The Arctic pipe when you have shifting ground, so to speak.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: And many of those would become unlevel, and move inches in a year and have to be

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: repaired and fixed. So that's one thing that comes to mind. Intake also has been an issue.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: The changing pattern and the fall sea storms, especially, have certainly impacted some of

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: our intake systems.

Text: Sorry to jump around a little bit, but you'd mentioned talking to operators and talking to

Text: anotherâ€¦ Relocating entirely.

Text: So I think it's easier to have those conversations in communities where you're seeing the

Text: [REDACTED], and the [REDACTED] is about to fall in the water. It's easy to have that

Text: conversation when you're under threat of a fire in the next few years versus long-term.

Text: Yeah, there's probably fewer people questioning whether it's happening or not.

Text: So the engineers at [REDACTED] on the state side put in a bunch of data for every potential

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: project, right? So [REDACTED] have engineers that put in for potential projects, right? So

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: they can say, "Community X over here has a failing water treatment plant, and we need

Text: to revamp the filtration system." So, they will put together a project with cost estimates,

Speaker: Interviewee

Text: "Which projects do we feel like we want to support?" And they support that with numbers

Text: funding. And that's all based on the funding that's available that year.

Speaker: Interviewee

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: unmet need continues to increase.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: You mentioned the costs to the customers, and how it oftentimes wasn't enough to cover

Text: the cost of operations. So, specifically, is it that customers have trouble paying their bills,

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: or is it there's not enough of them, or what?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah, that's a complicated question. The Alaska Rural Utility Collaborative, or ARUC,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: because there's a million acronyms for everything. So Alaska Rural Utility Collaborative,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: they have the best numbers on user fees and collection rates and what people are willing

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to pay, and so theyâ€¦ I don't know the exact numbers, but they'll go into a community,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: determine that people are willing to pay like $120 to $160 a month, right? And we talked

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: about really needing the managerial support. So they will be a partner to the community

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and help them run that water system, and help with collections and expenses and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: operator training. So they'll go in and assist a community.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: And what they've found is that they have a pretty high collection rate, like 90â€¦ Upwards

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: of 90%, and they certainly seem to run specials where people can apply their PFD and pay

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: for their water bill throughout the year. And they have other programs. So, this outside

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: third-party cooperative is going in and they're increasing user rates, and they have some

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: of the highest collection rates that any of the communities have. And then you go to

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: another community without that and they'll say, "Oh, people just won't pay their bills,"

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: and they'll have less than a 50% collection rate. So we see very different things in terms

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: of how much people are willing to pay and collection rates.

Text: Okay, and so you're saying that the primary difference, then, is ARUC specifically?

Text: We have the best numbers from ARUC, so most of what we know about rates and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: collectionâ€¦ Like collection rates and monthly user fees, are from ARUC, because they

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: track it so well, and they make that available. And another community may or may not be

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: tracking it well, and might not make it available. So what I know about user rates mostly

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: comes from ARUC, which is this third party program that is assisting a community with

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: running their system.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: What happens when people don't pay their bills?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah. Eventually the operators don't get paid. The water plant has a hard time purchasing

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: things that they need, like chemicals. They don't pay for testing. They really just literally

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: don't pay for anything that they can't afford. Parts, spare parts.

Text: What happens to theâ€¦ Does the water get shut off to people's homes, then?

Text: I mean, that would be a worst-case scenario, that would be a giant fail, but that could

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: happen, right? So we could have, like I'm thinking of one example where the filter went

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: down, and so you haveâ€¦ And they weren't at the time able to buy the parts they needed

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: to repair that. So you can either pump untreated water or you can turn it off, so to speak.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Yeah. I guess I was more thinking for if I'm an individual customer and I don't pay my bill.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: Interviewer 1
Text: Do I no longer get water at my house and everyone else does?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Wide-ranging practices. So, again, the best data we have on that comes from a ARUC.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Speaking from ARUC, they pay their operators to shut off the house after like 90 days of

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: nonpayment, right? So they have a pretty firm plan. They stick to that plan. What we find

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: in other communities is everything, right? So a wide variation of practices. But I have

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: heard from some operators that they don't want to turn off so-and-so's water, right?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: They've got a bunch of kids, or it's their grandfather and they may not want to do that.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: The managerial entity might not have firm policies to cause that to happen, as well. So

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: outside of ARUC, it varies community by community.

Text: Okay. [REDACTED], before we move on, is there anything else you wanted to drill down

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Yeah. I wanted to ask a couple questions about the community specifically. You've

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: mentioned a couple times throughout that your goal is to advocate for communities, and

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: you've worked directly with communities. What do you think water means to the public?

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: And can you expand a little bit more on public perceptions towards water services? I know

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: you started at the beginning, you talked a little bit about how people sometimes will use

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: traditional sources, but can you expand on that a little bit more?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah, sure. I did a project when I was at [REDACTED] that really explored the reasons that

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: people choose to use untreated water, so I think that's informed a lot of what I'm saying

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: here today. And the number one reason that people shared as far as why they prefer

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: untreated water that's not from the water plant is really just like a preference for natural

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: things, or, "This is the way that we've always done it. This is the way our elders did it."

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: We also heard some people say that they don't like the taste or the chemicals, that they

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: would share that it makes their coffee taste bad or funny. And then also, there's a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: convenience factor, right? So, in homes without running water, where they don't have

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: treated water directly coming out of their faucet, it's sometimes more work to get treated

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: water to your house than to use rainwater, right? So there's a convenience factor and

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: there's a cost factor, not just in terms of actual money that you pay for the water, but in

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: terms of manpower and resources and time to go collect the water.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: So those are some of the key themes that we found in [REDACTED] communities in this

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: region that we were working with, and that was really in order of preference, so a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: preference for natural things, and, "This is what we've always done," and, "This is a

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: cultural practice," that really ranked pretty highly.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: And when you're talking about operator training, as well, do you think that same tendency

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: towards like, "Oh, this is how we've done it," or, "This is how we've always ran the

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: system," does that come to play when you're talking about operator training as well? And

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: do you have any suggestions toâ€¦ Or any times where you've seen it be very impactful,

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: the way that people are training operators, in terms of using their knowledge that they

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: already have based on knowledge from elders or from their previous work? That was a

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: long-winded question, so let me know if you want me to rephrase.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah. No, I definitely have seen operators who may really be hesitant to put any chemicals

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: in the water, so that is a real thing. And I have seen operators have a breakthrough

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: moment when, especially with breakpoint chlorination, where if you reach the right level

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: of treatment, the water coming out doesn't taste or smell like chemicals, right?

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Yeah.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: So if you reach that right mix of treatment, you're having good, finished water at the end

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: that doesn't smell like chlorine, it doesn't taste like bleach, and it makes your coffee taste

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: good. So I think if you can convince an operator that like, "We can make good water that

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: people will like, and still use the proper treatment processes," I mean, that's the dream,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: right?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: But especially with fluorides, so as somebody with a public health background, part of my

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: work is not just to have water that's free from microorganisms, but also water that's

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: healthful, and fluoride is a part of that. And we don't have very much community water

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: fluoridation in the region, and we have many operators who are not wanting to add

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: fluoride. It's not required, like chlorine, in a lot of places. So there's just generally like,

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: don't want to add more chemicals to water. I do feel like that's an overarching attitude.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Okay, and that's because theâ€¦ Do you think that's a cultural relationship with water, that,

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: just tendency towards not wanting to add more to water, and wanting to use natural

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: resources?

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: I think so, maybe.

Speaker: Interviewer 2
Text: Okay.

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: Yeah. I mean, part of that is speculation, but part of that is, that was one of the themes

Speaker: Interviewee
Text: that came up in the research that I was doing as well, so it supports that.
